ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: Electrochemical reduction of CO2 (ECO2RR) to formate is one of effective approaches to achieve carbon recycling processes. Despite Bi nanosheets (NSs) have been proven to be highly selective in ECO2RR to formate, the understanding of the true active sites is needed to further dig out the potential of catalytic activity of Bi NSs. In this work, we developed a rational synthesis approach to manipulate the basal-/edge-plane ratio of Bi NSs via topotactic reduction of (004)-oriented Bi5O7I NSs and (102)-oriented BiOI NSs to reveal the contribution of basal and edge planes on the performance of ECO2RR. In comparison with edge-oriented Bi NSs, basal-oriented Bi NSs show higher catalytic activity. DFT calculations have proven that the competition of the kinetically favored HER would be inhibited on basal planes of Bi NSs, indicating the increasement of the proportion of basal planes on Bi NSs or Bi based 2D catalysts improves ECO2RR conversion efficiency.

ce:section.ce:para: The rapid devolepment of modern industry leads to the accelerated depletion of fossil fuels and the fast increase of CO2 concentration in the atmosphere. Then along comes the energy crisis and global warming. Therefore, growing attention has been paid to capture and utilize CO2 [1â3]. Electrocatalytic CO2 reduction reaction (ECO2RR) utilizes renewable electricity to transform CO2 into valuable fuels and chemicals, which is a promising approach to achieve carbon recycling processes [4â6]. Formate is an important liquid product of ECO2RR with a high product value per electron, which has been widely applied in hydrogen storage and fuel cells [7â10]. Two-dimensional (2D) Bi NSs has been demonstrated for ECO2RR with high formate selectivity, since it thermodynamically favors the adsorption of *OCOH over *COOH [11]. But even superior 2D Bi NSs or Bi based catalysts are used, the kinetically favored hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) is still existing. Therefore, identifying the active sites of HER and ECO2RR would be helpful for further digging out the potential of catalytical activity of 2D Bi NSs or Bi based catalysts.

In general, the edge-plane of 2D nanosheets has always been considered to be the active sites while the basal-plane has been regarded as catalytic inert sites for the simple HER [12]. However, it is difficult to identify the true active sites of 2D nanosheets for the complex ECO2RR. In this work, different oriented Bi NSs have been used as model to explore the effective active sites for ECO2RR to formate. Typically, Bi NSs can be obtained from exfoliation method [13â15], chemical reducation process[16,17] and electroreduction of pre-synthesized BiOX [18â22] (XCl, Br, I), BiVO4 [23], Bi@Bi2O3 [24], BiPO4 [25], Bi2O2CO3 [26], Bi-MOF [27] and so on. Inspired by these pioneering reports, a controllable method is developed to adjust the ratio of basal and edge planes in a single Bi nanosheet by electroreduction of different oriented bismuth oxyiodide nanosheets. During the electroreduction process, I and O atoms can be dynamically removed, and the skeleton of Bi remains, indicating that the original bismuth oxyiodide nanosheets provide templates for the catalysts functioned in the ECO2RR [28]. In this work, (004)-oriented Bi5O7I NSs and (102)-oriented BiOI NSs were used as templates, which were synthesized by a facile electrochemical exfoliation method for the first time. (004)-oriented Bi5O7I NSs and (102)-oriented BiOI NSs can be transformed to basal plane (003)-oriented Bi NSs and edge plane (012)-oriented Bi NSs via electroreduction. The theoretical model of Bi atoms rearranging in Bi5O7I and BiOI lattices under cathodic applied potential reveals the possible topological transformation process of basal- and edge-orientated Bi NSs.

The catalytic activity of HER and ECO2RR on basal- and edge-oriented Bi NSs have been carefully discussed to identify the true active sites of the complex ECO2RR. Edge-oriented Bi NSs exhibit larger Faradaic efficiency (FE) and current densities for HER than that of basal-oriented Bi NSs. On the contrary, basal-oriented Bi NSs exhibit larger FE and partial current densities for formate over edge-oriented Bi NSs. Specifically, basal-oriented Bi NSs exhibit high FE for formate (FEformate) over 90% within a broad potential window from â0.38 to â1.07 V vs. RHE (all potentials hereafter are given with respect to RHE). The highest FEformate of basal-oriented Bi NSs reaches 98.0% at â0.68 V. Moreover, DFT calculations were performed to further investigate the ECO2RR as well as HER activity on basal and edge planes of Bi NSs. The calculation results show that there is a very similar ECO2RR activity on basal and edge planes of Bi NSs, while, the HER would be obviously inhibited over basal planes of Bi NSs. Combination study of experiment results and DFT calculations proven that increasing the proportion of basal planes on Bi NSs or Bi based 2D catalysts will provide an effective way for inhibiting the HER and promoting the selectivity of ECO2RR. This work offers insight to design efficient CO2RR 2D electrocatalysts with micrometer-scale lateral structure.

The synthesis process was carried out using a two-electrode system in an H-type cell by electrochemical exfoliation method. The Bi flakes and Pt foil were used as the cathode and the anode. The freshly prepared 0.5 M NaI aqueous solution was used as the electrolyte. A direct current (DC) potential of 20 V was applied to drive the exfoliation of Bi flakes for about 4 h under magnetic stirring. The exfoliated Nano-Bi reacted with oxygen from air and Iâ from NaI solution (the pH value of 14) to form Bi5O7I NSs. The obtained white solid was collected through vacuum filtration and then washed with a plenty of water to remove the electrolyte. Afterwards, the as-prepared white solid was dried at 60 Â°C for 6 h.

BiOI NSs were prepared by Nano-Bi reacting with oxygen from air and Iâ from NaI solution (the pH value of 6.5) under magnetic stirring. Firstly, Bi NSs were prepared by electrochemical exfoliation method modified from our previously reported work [15]. The Bi flakes and Pt foil were used as the cathode and the anode. A direct current (DC) potential of 20 V was applied to drive the exfoliation of Bi flakes in 0.5 M NaI aqueous solution under N2 atmosphere in the ice bath for about 4 h. The obtained black solid was collected by vacuum filtration and then washed with a plenty of water to remove the electrolyte, finally dried in vacuum oven at 60 Â°C for 6 h. Afterwards, 10 mg of the as-prepared black powders were dispersed into 20 mL 0.5 M NaI aqueous solution (the pH value is 6.5) via mild sonication for 10 min and then magnetic stirring for 4 h. The obtained yellow solid was collected through vacuum filtration and then washed with a plenty of water to remove the electrolyte. Afterwards, the collected yellow solid was dried at 60 Â°C for 6 h.

ce:section.ce:para: 30 mg of the as-prepared Bi5O7I/ BiOI NSs was dispersed into 20 mL deionized water via mild sonication for 10 min, then 50 mg NaBH4 was put into the suspension solution under intensity magnetic stirring for 5 min. The obtained black solid was collected through vacuum filtration and then washed with a plenty of water. The collected black solid was dried in vacuum oven at 60 Â°C for 6 h.

Cyclic voltammetry (CV) and Linear sweep voltammetry (LSV) measurements were carried out in a 0.5 M KHCO3 aqueous solution saturated with Ar/CO2 in a conventional three-electrode cell. The three-electrode cell comprises a Pt foil counter electrode, an Ag/AgCl (3 M KCl) reference electrode and a glassy carbon (0.0707 cm2) as the working electrode. 10 mg catalyst and 50 ÂµL nafion (5%) were dispersed into 950 ÂµL ethanol under sonication for 1 h to form a homogeneous catalyst ink. 7 ÂµL catalyst ink was drop-casted onto glassy carbon and dried under an infrared lamp. In order to convert the potentials (E) to the reversible hydrogen electrode (RHE) reference scale, the following formula was used: E (vs. RHE) = E (vs. Ag/AgCl) + 0.0591 V Ã pH+ 0.222 V. The pH value of the Ar/CO2-saturated 0.5 M KHCO3 electrolyte solution is about 8.8/7.2. Electrolysis process was performed in an H-type cell (with a glass frit as the separator) and a flow cell configuration (The introduction about flow cell configuration can be seen in Supporting Information). Each compartment of the H-type cell contained 23 mL of 0.5 M KHCO3 electrolyte solution with the headspace approximate to 22 mL. A Pt mesh was used as the counter electrode, an Ag/AgCl (3 M KCl) was used as the reference electrode and a modified carbon paper (1 cm Ã 1 cm, 100 ÂµL catalyst ink was loaded on one side) was used as the working electrode. Before electrolysis, the cell was bubbled with 80 sccm CO2 flow for 15 min. During electrolysis process, 20 sccm CO2 flow was continuously bubbled. The solutions in both compartments of the H-type cell were stirred during electrolysis process. The gaseous products were analyzed by Gas Chromatograph (GC). The liquid product was quantitatively analyzed by 1 H nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) with 500 ÂµL electrolyte mixed with 200 ÂµL D2O and 100 ÂµL DMSO with a certain concentration used as an internal standard. ce:section.ce:section-title: Controllable synthesis of bismuth NSs with various basal- /edge-plane ratios
ce:section.ce:para:
As illustrated in Fig. 1, (004)-oriented Bi5O7I NSs and (102)-oriented BiOI NSs were firstly synthesized by electrochemical exfoliation method, in which Bi flakes and Pt foil were used as the cathode and the anode, and 0.5âM NaI aqueous solution was used as the electrolyte. When applying a cathodic potential, the intercalation of Na+ cations from the electrolyte into negatively charged Bi layers leads to the exfoliation of bulk Bi (Physical properties of bulk Bi can be found in Fig. S1) to Nano-Bi (Physical properties of Nano-Bi can be found in Fig. S2a, b). The exfoliated Nano-Bi is prone to be oxidized and then combined with Iâ from electrolyte to form BixOyI (Photograph of the as-prepared BixOyI is shown in Fig. S2c), due to the existence of abundant oxygen in the air. Moreover, different oriented BixOyI were controllably synthesized under different pH conditions. (102)-oriented BiOI NSs were synthesized at a pH value of 6.5 while (004)-oriented Bi5O7I NSs were formed with enough OHâ since BiOI can combine with the surrounding OHâ anions to form Bi5O7I (Detailed synthetic process is shown in the Sections 2.1 and 2.2). Bismuth oxyiodide can be transformed to Bi at external applied cathodic potential. During the electroreduction process, I and O atoms can be dynamically removed while Bi skeleton remains, indicating that the original layered bismuth oxyiodide provides template to form layered Bi [18,28]. Inspired by these pioneering works, we applied electroreduction to obtain basal- and edge-oriented Bi NSs directly from (004)-oriented Bi5O7I NSs and (102)-oriented BiOI NSs. Details about this topotactic transformation is carefully discussed in the Section 3.2.

X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns of the prepared Bi5O7I NSs before and after topotactic transformation are shown in Fig. 2a. All the diffraction peaks of the prepared sample shown in the top of Fig. 2a could be indexed to orthorhombic Bi5O7I (JCPDS card No. 40â0548). It is noteworthy that the relative intensity of (004) peak of the prepared Bi5O7I NSs is much higher than the other peaks. The relative intensity ratio of (004)/(312) is 10.3 for the prepared Bi5O7I NSs, while it is only 1.30 for the standard Bi5O7I (JCPDS card No. 40-0548), which implies that the synthesized Bi5O7I NSs is preferred oriented on (004) planes (denoted as (004)-oriented Bi5O7I in this work). Microscopic characterizations were conducted to reveal the morphology features of (004)-oriented Bi5O7I NSs. The transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images in Fig. 2b and c show that (004)-oriented Bi5O7I exhibits a ribbon-like nanosheet morphology with the average length and width of 2.5âÂµm and 300ânm, respectively. The selected area electron diffraction (SAED) pattern obtained over a large piece of Bi5O7I NS is shown in the inset of Fig. 2c. A single set of diffraction spots exhibits three lattice spacings of 0.271, 0.268 and 0.191ânm, which are indexed to (600), (020) and (620) plane of orthorhombic Bi5O7I, respectively. The above results proved that the as-prepared Bi5O7I exposed [001] plane in the vertical direction, which is consistent with the results reported by Ye et al. [29,30]. Moreover, the high-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM) image of (004)-oriented Bi5O7I NSs in Fig. 2d reveals obvious lattice fringes corresponding to (600) plane of orthorhombic Bi5O7I. Atomic force microscopy (AFM) is used to measure the thickness of the prepared samples. The thickness of (004)-oriented Bi5O7I NSs is measured to be about 4.31ânm in Fig. S3a. Furthermore, the statistics distribution of area to thickness ratio of (004)-oriented Bi5O7I NSs was investigated. The area to thickness ratio of (004)-oriented Bi5O7I NSs is concentrated on 100â200âÂµm (Fig. S4a), which further confirm that the prepared Bi5O7I NSs is oriented on (004) basal planes.

(004)-oriented Bi5O7I NSs can be used as the template to transform to (003)-oriented Bi NSs via electroreduction. As shown in the bottom of Fig. 2a, all the XRD peaks assigned to Bi5O7I disappeared after the electroreduction, whilst new peaks indexed to rhombohedral Bi (JCPDS card No. 44-1246) were formed. The diffraction peak intensity of (003) planes is very high and the intensity of (003)/(012) reaches 4.0, indicating that electroreduced Bi is preferred oriented on (003) planes. The crystalline structure model of Bi NSs (shown in Fig. 2e) reveals that (003) plane is the basal plane of Bi NSs and therefore (003)-oriented Bi NSs is denoted as basal-oriented Bi NSs in this work. Moreover, the surface valence state of basal-oriented Bi NSs was tested by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS). Although the oxygen has been carefully isolated in the pseudo in-situ XPS measurement process (details are described in Supporting Information), Bi-O species formed inevitably on the surface of basal-oriented Bi NSs when electrolysis stopped [31], because O2 produced on the anode during electrolysis process can transfer to catholyte from the glass frit separator of H-type Cell. As shown in Fig. S5a, Bi0 and Bi3+ were detected on the surface of basal-oriented Bi NSs by pseudo in-situ XPS analysis. TEM and HRTEM measurements were also conducted to study the morphology and microscopic structure of basal-oriented Bi NSs. The TEM image in Fig. 2e reveals that basal-oriented Bi also exhibits a ribbon-like nanosheet morphology with lateral micron size, which is similar to that of (004)-oriented Bi5O7I, suggesting that Bi skeleton keeps stable during electroreduction process. Furthermore, as shown in HRTEM image (Fig. 2f), the lattice spacing of basal-oriented Bi NSs is measured to be 0.33ânm, corresponding to the (012) plane of rhombohedral Bi. Basal-oriented Bi NSs with lateral micron size tend to flat on the carbon film, which is easier to capture the lattice fringe of (012) plane. In addition, the average thickness of basal-oriented Bi NSs is about 3.36ânm, corresponding to 8â9 layers of Bi atomic layers, which is measured from the AFM image in Fig. 2g.

The crystal structure and morphology of (102)-oriented BiOI NSs and it electroreduced edge-oriented Bi have been investigated as well. Fig. 3a shows the XRD patterns of the prepared BiOI NSs before and after electroreduction. All the diffraction peaks shown in the top of Fig. 3a exhibit that the prepared BiOI NSs were indexed to tetragonal BiOI (JCPDS card No.10-0455). The intensity of (102) plane is obviously higher than the other diffraction peaks, suggesting the prepared BiOI NSs is preferred oriented on (102) planes (denoted as (102)-oriented BiOI NSs in this work). Microscopic characterizations were conducted to reveal the morphology features of (102)-oriented BiOI NSs. The scanning electron microscope (SEM) and TEM images in Fig. 3b and c show that the morphology of (102)-oriented BiOI NSs is a hierarchical flower-like structure assembled by multiple nanosheets. The SAED pattern obtained over a piece of BiOI NS is shown in the inset of Fig. 3c. A single set of diffraction spots exhibits two lattice spacings of 0.282 and 0.199ânm, which are indexed to the (110) and (200) planes of tetragonal BiOI, respectively. The above results proved that the as-prepared BiOI NSs exposed [001] plane in the vertical direction, which is consistent with the results reported by Li et al. [18]. Moreover, the HRTEM image of BiOI in Fig. 3d reveals obvious lattice fringes corresponding to (110) plane of tetragonal BiOI. The average thickness of (102)-oriented BiOI NSs is about 4.47ânm measured in Fig. S3b, which is similar to that of (004)-oriented Bi5O7I NSs. Moreover, the statistics distribution of area to thickness ratio of (102)-oriented BiOI NSs is concentrated on 10â20âÂµm (Fig. S4b). In comparison, the basal plane area of (004)-oriented Bi5O7I NSs is about 10 times to that of (102)-oriented BiOI NSs.

(102)-oriented BiOI NSs can also transform to rhombohedral Bi NSs (JCPDS card No. 44-1246) during electroreduction process and the corresponding XRD pattern is shown in the bottom of Fig. 3a. The pronounced reflection from (012) diffraction peak indicates that (102)-oriented BiOI has topologically reduced to (012)-oriented Bi with a (012)/(003) intensity ratio of 2.37. (012) plane is the edge plane of Bi NSs, which can be seen from the crystalline structure model of Bi in Fig. 3e, and therefore (012)-oriented Bi NSs is denoted as edge-oriented Bi NSs in this work. The pseudo in-situ XPS is also used to investigate the surface valence state of edge-oriented Bi NSs. Edge-oriented Bi NSs with 0 and +3 valence states of Bi is shown in Fig. S5b, which is similar to that of basal-oriented Bi NSs. The morphology and microscopic structure of edge-oriented Bi NSs were investigated by TEM and HRTEM measurements. The TEM image in Fig. 3e reveals that edge-oriented Bi NSs exhibits the nanosheet morphology which is also similar to the template (102)-oriented BiOI NSs. As shown in HRTEM image (Fig. 3f), the lattice spacing of edge-oriented Bi NSs is measured to be 0.33ânm, corresponding to the (012) plane of rhombohedral Bi. In addition, the average thickness of edge-oriented Bi NSs is about 3.41ânm (measured in Fig. 3g), corresponding to 8â9 layers of Bi atomic layers, which is also similar to that of basal-oriented Bi NSs.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Mechanism of bismuth oxyiodide topotactically transformed to Bi with controllable basal- /edge-plane ratios
ce:section.ce:para: Electroreduction process provides a mild reducing condition, in which a controllable amount of electrons are constantly provided at a suitable cathodic applied potential and the slow conversion kinetics can keep the ultrathin nanosheet morphology [32]. The layered bismuth oxyiodide can provide template for forming layered Bi by electroreduction way [18â20] because the typical bismuth oxyiodide has open layered crystalline structures with bismuth-oxygen layer (such as Bi2O2 2+) sandwiched between two slices of I atoms through strong electrovalent bonds [33]. Therefore, (004)-oriented Bi5O7I NSs and (102)-oriented BiOI NSs are used as template to transform to basal plane (003)-oriented Bi NSs and edge plane (012)-oriented Bi NSs in this work. The rearrangement of Bi atoms in Bi5O7I and BiOI lattices under cathodic applied potential is speculated in Fig. 4a and b to understand the topotactic reduction process.

Combination with the XRD patterns and TEM images of (004)-oriented Bi5O7I NSs and its electroreduced Bi NSs, we speculate that a majority of Bi atoms tend to rearrange with the nearby Bi atoms and orient along the direction of Z axis when I and O atoms were removed from (004)-oriented Bi5O7I NSs under cathodic applied potential. The possible theoretical transformation process of (004)-oriented Bi5O7I NSs topotactically reduced to (003)-oriented Bi NSs is shown in Fig. 4a. During the electroreduction process, I and O atoms were dynamically removed from (004)-oriented Bi5O7I template while the Bi skeleton remained [28]. It is remarkable that the (004)-oriented Bi5O7I NSs provided a template for Bi atoms to rearrange with the nearby Bi atoms and still orient along the direction of Z axis to form (003)-orientated Bi NSs. In addition, the possible theoretical transformation process of (102)-oriented BiOI NSs topotactically reduced to (012)-oriented Bi NSs is shown in Fig. 4b. In the similar way, (102)-oriented BiOI NSs provided a template for Bi atoms to rearrange with the nearby Bi atoms and orient on (012) planes under cathodic applied potential. Based on the above discussion, the rearrangement of Bi atoms during topotactic reduction of (004)-oriented Bi5O7I NSs and (102)-oriented BiOI NSs is dependent on the arrangement of Bi atoms in their precursor, which is the crystal structure of bismuth oxyiodides.

(003) and (012)-oriented Bi NSs were obtained in the mild electroreduction process with (004)-oriented Bi5O7I NSs and (102)-oriented BiOI NSs used as the template, respectively. In order to further investigate the crucial role of the precursor template for the formation of (003) and (012)-oriented Bi NSs, NaBH4 chemical reduction (details are shown in the Section 2.3) instead of electroreduction was also conducted. NaBH4 is an effective reducing agent which provides eight electrons per molecule for reducing in an aqueous solution. So NaBH4 chemical reduction method usually provides a drastic reducing condition. A plenty of electrons produced instantaneously when a suitable amount of NaBH4 was added into an aqueous solution with (004)-oriented Bi5O7I NSs or (102)-oriented BiOI NSs uniformly dispersed. Bi3+ ions were reduced to Bi0 atoms momently, following that I and O atoms were removed instantaneously from Bi5O7I and BiOI lattices under NaBH4 chemical reduction (related equations are shown in Supporting Information). The crystal structure of Bi5O7I and BiOI collapses under the drastic NaBH4 reducing condition. Eventually, the reduced Bi0 atoms tended to rearrange with the nearby Bi0 atoms and orient on a more stable (012) plane [34]. Crystal structure and morphology of chemically reduced Bi are shown in Fig. S6 and S7.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Basal vs. edge-oriented Bi NSs on ECO2RR and HER performance
ce:section.ce:para: The cyclic voltammetric (CV) curves of (004)-oriented Bi5O7I NSs and (102)-oriented BiOI NSs modified electrodes in a CO2-saturated 0.5âM KHCO3 aqueous solution at a scan rate of 100âmVâsâ1 are shown in Fig. S8. A rapid increase of reduction current is observed when the potential is more negative than â0.85âV, which is attributed to the reduction of Bi3+ to Bi0 [35]. Linear-sweep voltammetric (LSV) curves of basal- and edge-oriented Bi NSs modified electrodes in 0.5âM KHCO3 aqueous solution under CO2 and Ar atmosphere are shown in Fig. 5a. Basal- and edge-oriented Bi electrodes exhibit a larger current density and a less negative onset potential under CO2 atmosphere than that under Ar atmosphere. A rapid increase in reduction current is observed when the potential is more negative than â0.4âV, which indicates the possibility of using basal- and edge-oriented Bi NSs as catalysts for ECO2RR.

Bulk electrolysis was conducted to further explore the HER and ECO2RR catalytic activity of basal- and edge-oriented Bi NSs. Formate was the only liquid product detected in the liquid phase using 1H1 H NMR measurement. Gaseous products including CO and H2 were detected using GC. H2 was identified as the major by-product and negligible CO (FEs for CO are less than 2.0% at all applied potentials) was detected for basal- and edge-oriented Bi NSs in an H-type cell. The FEs for formate and H2 at applied potentials are presented in Fig. 5b. Basal-oriented Bi NSs exhibit relative larger FE for formate (FEformate) and lower FE for H2 than that of edge-oriented Bi NSs from â0.55 to â0.95âV. The largest FEformate on basal-oriented Bi NSs reaches (93.3âÂ±â1.5)% at â0.85âV, while it is (91.0âÂ±â2.0)% at â0.95âV on edge-oriented Bi NSs. The FE for H2 on basal-oriented Bi NSs is only (3.8âÂ±â0.1)% at â0.85âV, while it reaches (7.7âÂ±â0.3)% for edge-oriented Bi NSs. Moreover, edge-oriented Bi electrode prepared by NaBH4 chemical reduction of (004)-oriented Bi5O7I NSs also shows higher FEs for H2 than that of basal-oriented Bi electrode prepared by electroreduction of (004)-oriented Bi5O7I NSs at applied potential (Fig. S9b). In addition, the current densities for HER on basal- and edge-oriented Bi NSs are shown in Fig. 5c. The current densities for HER on edge-oriented Bi NSs are superior to that on basal-oriented Bi NSs at applied potentials. From above results, edge-oriented Bi NSs exhibit higher catalytic activity towards HER than that of basal-oriented Bi NSs, which is similar to bulk Bi that edges show main catalytic activity towards HER [36].

In order to further inhibit HER and raise CO2 utilization efficiency, the flow cell configuration which could separate CO2 and electrolyte to improve CO2 mass transport was used to evaluate the ECO2RR performance of basal- and edge-oriented Bi NSs [37]. Fig. 5d and Fig. S10a,b exhibit that the FEformate of basal-oriented Bi NSs reaches over 90% in a wide potential range from â0.38 to â1.07âV in a flow cell configuration, while edge-oriented Bi NSs achieve the similar performance in a narrow potential range from â0.68 to â1.07âV. The highest FEformate of basal-oriented Bi NSs reaches 98.0% at â0.68âV, while it is 96.7% at â0.84âV on the edge-oriented Bi NSs (corresponding 1H NMR spectra is shown in Fig. S11). Preliminary stability test of basal-oriented Bi NSs is shown in Fig. 5e, a stable FE for formate over 96% and a stable partial current density for formate about 90âmAâcmâ2 were sustained for 7000âs at â0.68âV. Moreover, the crystal structure and morphology of basal- and edge-oriented Bi NSs after long term ECO2RR remain unchanged to that before ECO2RR (Fig. S12) indicating the structural stability of basal- and edge-oriented Bi NSs during ECO2RR process. In addition, Fig. 5d shows that basal-oriented Bi NSs exhibit a superior current density for formate than that of edge-oriented Bi NSs at applied potentials. The largest partial current density for formate of basal-oriented Bi NSs reaches (181.2âÂ±â10.2) mA cmâ2 at â1.07âV, while it is only (135.8âÂ±â9.8) mA cmâ2 on the edge-oriented Bi NSs, which indicates that basal-oriented Bi NSs can utilize electrons more effectively for ECO2RR.

Tafel analysis is used to understand the electrochemical activity and kinetics of ECO2RR on basal- and edge-oriented Bi NSs. Tafel plots are obtained by using the logarithm of partial current density for formate versus the applied potential (Fig. 5f). The Tafel slope value of basal-oriented Bi NSs (126âmV decâ1) is approximate to the theoretical values of 119âmV decâ1, which predicts that *CO2/*CO2ââ is the rate-determining step [38]. Moreover, compared to edge-oriented Bi NSs (149âmV decâ1), basal-oriented Bi NSs exhibit a lower Tafel slope of 126âmV decâ1, indicating a faster electron transfer rate on basal-oriented Bi NSs [39]. The electrochemically active surface area (ECSA) was calculated to evaluate the intrinsic activity of basal- and edge-oriented Bi NSs, as shown in Fig. S13. The double layer capacitances of basal- and edge-oriented Bi NSs are 0.054 and 0.051 mF cmâ2, respectively, implying that ECSA is not the key factor leading to the different ECO2RR performance of basal- and edge-oriented Bi NSs. The key factor for the different catalytic activity on basal- and edge-oriented Bi NSs is the proportion of basal planes on Bi NSs. The ECO2RR as well as HER on (003) basal and (012) edge planes of Bi were further investigated by DFT calculations.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Reaction pathways and the Gibbs free energy changes of ECO2RR and HER over basal and edge plane of Bi
ce:section.ce:para: DFT calculations were performed to further investigate the ECO2RR as well as HER on (003) and (012) planes of Bi, which can provide more insights for understanding of the difference between basal- and edge-oriented Bi NSs. The detailed reaction pathways and the Gibbs free energy changes of ECO2RR and HER over Bi(003) and Bi(012) surfaces were obtained from the DFT calculations. The Bi(003) and Bi(012) surfaces were modeled using (4âÃâ4) and (3âÃâ4) four-layers unit slabs with ~20âÃ vacuum. More details for modeling and computational methods are included in the Supporting Information.

The Gibbs free energy changes for HER for Bi(003) and Bi(012) are shown in Fig. 6a. The hydrogen adsorption free energies (ÎGH*), which were widely reported as the key descriptor for HER activity in acid and neutral pH electrolytes [40], were positive over both surfaces, therefore the lower ÎGH* should give the better HER performance. To obtain the ÎGH*, various H adsorption sites were considered and the ÎGH* was calculated based on the most energetically favorable adsorption mode as shown in Fig. 6c, d. The corresponding ÎGH* was 0.76âeV over Bi(012), which was 0.32âeV lower than that over Bi(003) (1.08âeV), suggesting that the better HER performance over Bi(012) than Bi(003). This result indicates that the HER would be inhibited over Bi(003) compared to Bi(012), which is in consistent with the experimental results shown in Fig. 5c (Current density test of basal- and edge-oriented Bi NSs for HER).

The Gibbs free energy changes along the reaction pathway in ECO2RR are shown in Fig. 6b, it could be observed that the largest free energy increase showed in the first H+/e- pair transfer in the CO2 electroreduction to form *OCHO. Therefore, the adsorption free energies for *OCHO (G*OCHO) could be the key descriptor for the reactivity in ECO2RR. The most energetically favorable adsorption mode for *OCHO were illustrated in Fig. 6e, f. Only very slight difference of Gibbs free energy changes (about 0.06âeV) was showed for G*OCHO over Bi(003) and Bi(012), which suggests a very similar ECO2RR activity on these two surfaces. Considering the significant HER performance on Bi(012) predicted by the calculation, a higher FE for ECO2RR over basal-oriented Bi NSs ((003) plane oriented Bi NSs) could be inferred from the calculation results, which is also consist with the experiment result.

In conclusion, (004) oriented Bi5O7I NSs and (102) oriented BiOI NSs were synthesized by a facile electrochemical cathodic exfoliation method. (004) oriented Bi5O7I NSs and (102) oriented BiOI NSs were used as templates to transform to basal- and edge-oriented Bi NSs via electroreduction. The catalytic activity of basal- and edge-oriented Bi NSs for ECO2RR and HER were investigated to identify the true active sites on Bi NSs for the ECO2RR. In comparison, basal-oriented Bi NSs show higher ECO2RR selectivity and lower HER catalytic activity than that of edge-oriented Bi NSs. The highest FEformate of basal-oriented Bi NSs reaches 98.0% at â0.68âV, the largest partial current density for formate of basal-oriented Bi NSs reaches (181.2âÂ±â10.2) mA cmâ2 at â1.07âV. Moreover, DFT calculations indicate that ECO2RR activity on basal and edge planes of Bi is very similar while the HER would be inhibited on basal planes of Bi. So the higher FE and partial current density for formate on basal-oriented Bi NSs is due to (003) basal plane, which exhibits low catalytic activity for the competition HER and promotes the selectivity of ECO2RR. This work provides an effective strategy for inhibiting the HER and promoting the selectivity of ECO2RR by increase the proportion of basal planes on Bi NSs or Bi based 2D materials. The present results provide new insights into design efficient 2D electrocatalysts for ECO2RR with micrometer-scale lateral structure.
